Section 301 of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include provisions for setting appropriate levels for aggregate means-tested welfare spending for fiscal years, with limitations on exceeding federal means-tested levels. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to set limits on aggregate means-tested welfare spending, not exceeding federal levels adjusted for inflation. In fiscal year 2016, the limit is $825 billion, in 2017 it is $750 billion, and from 2018 onwards, it is adjusted based on inflation for medical assistance programs. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 sets limits on means-tested welfare spending, adjusted for inflation. Welfare spending is adjusted based on the weighted price index for personal consumption expenditures, excluding health products and services. SEC. 304. ALLOCATIONS OF MEANS-TESTED WELFARE SPENDING. Section 302 of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include a Means-Tested Welfare Spending Limit, which further divides amounts for aggregate means-tested welfare spending in budget resolutions. This division includes allocations for discretionary and mandatory means-tested welfare spending. The Means-Tested Welfare Spending Limit is added to Section 302 of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974, dividing amounts for aggregate means-tested welfare spending in budget resolutions. This includes allocations for discretionary and mandatory means-tested welfare spending. It establishes a process for reporting mandatory means-tested welfare spending to relevant committees and sets a point of order in the House of Representatives and the Senate for considering related legislation. The amendment adds an exception to the allocation of new budget authority or outlays if the average monthly unemployment rate exceeds 7.5 percent in the preceding fiscal year. Amendment to the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 adds exception for allocation of new budget authority or outlays if average monthly unemployment rate exceeds 7.5 percent in preceding fiscal year. Conforming amendment made to Section 302(b) by adding subsection (h). SEC. 305. RECONCILIATION. Section 310(a) of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to specify changes in new budget authority for mandatory means-tested welfare spending, directing committees to recommend changes to align with the Congressional Budget Office baseline level of spending. In amending Section 310(a) of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974, changes are made to align new budget authority for mandatory means-tested welfare spending with the Congressional Budget Office baseline level of spending. Additionally, adjustments are made to paragraph (5) by inserting a new paragraph (4) for the fiscal year. TITLE IV--GRANTS TO PROMOTE SELF-SUFFICIENCY

Purpose of this title is to encourage States to develop policies promoting self-sufficiency, prosperity, reducing poverty, and Government dependence through grants provided under the Social Security Act. The Secretary may provide grants to States to reward reductions in poverty and Government dependence, and increases in self-sufficiency. Grants in the amount of $100,000,000 will be allocated to the 3 States with the greatest percentage increases in self-sufficiency ratio compared to fiscal year 2007. States must have a self-sufficiency ratio greater than that of fiscal year 2007 to be eligible for grants. The term 'self-sufficient family' refers to a family whose income exceeds the poverty line, excluding means-tested welfare spending. 'Self-sufficiency ratio' is the number of self-sufficient families headed by able-bodied individuals under 63 years old in a State divided by... The term 'State' refers to the 50 States and the District of Columbia. For grants under this title, $300,000,000 is authorized to be appropriated to the Secretary for fiscal year 2016 and each succeeding fiscal year. TITLE V--PROHIBITION ON FUNDING OF ABORTION

SEC. 501. No Federal funds shall be used for abortions.

SEC. 502. Federal funds cannot be used for health plans covering abortion.

SEC. 503. Tax benefits related to abortion are prohibited. SEC. 503 prohibits tax benefits for abortion expenses or health plans covering abortion starting after the enactment date. SEC. 504 allows the purchase of separate abortion coverage or health benefits coverage with non-federal funds. SEC. 505 allows non-Federal health benefits coverage providers to offer abortion coverage using funds not authorized by Federal law. SEC. 506 addresses abortions related to rape, incest, or preserving the life of the mother. Abortion limitations do not apply in cases of rape, incest, or when a woman's life is in danger due to a physical disorder or illness certified by a physician.
